content:
Do you see your mail account in the Folder Pane and all of it's folders and do they contain emails ?

Do you mean you cannot download new mail ? Can you send emails ?

Do you have an Imap or Pop mail account ? How to find out if unsure...

  • Account Settings
  • select 'Server Settings' for the account.
  • Look top right for 'Server Type' and you will see either 'Imap Mail Server' or 'Pop Mail Server'

If it's an IMAP mail account what quota limit have you reached ? In Folder Pane

  • Right click on imap mail account 'Inbox' folder and select 'Properties'
  • Select the 'Quota' tab to see information.

It would be useful to know current set up so we can advise if something is wrong. In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • scroll down to 'Mail and News Account' section
  • Copy all the information/data in that area and paste it into this forum.

If Thunderbird has been accessing the server and auto downloading emails then it's likely you had Thunderbird remember your passwords.

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll down to Passwords section
  • clickon 'Saved Passwords' button
  • Clickon 'Show Passwords' button

If you see a 'Windows SEcurity' pop up window asking for password you may ask what password it it wanting? It means - when you start up computer and it asks you to Enter password to access desktop - that is the password it wants.

If account is Imap You need to use the imap://account... password If account is Pop You need to use the mailbox://account...password.

You might not be able to download emails because there is no room on the server. Basically server is not receiving new mail so Thunderbird cannot download something that does not exist. But you would need to access your webmail account to find out if there are new mail. Access your webmail account via a browser using the password you found in Thunderbird. If it does not work, you will see a 'forgotten password' link which you have to use and then follow instructions to get access to your webmail account.

If you were using a POP mail account : If there are no new emails in webmail account, then nothing can get downloaded. Delete all the very old mail - after all you should have a copy on computer in profile. Empty the server Spam folder. Empty the server TRash folder. This should free up some space on server, so new mail can be received.

If you were using an IMAP mail account : If there are no new emails in webmail account, then nothing can get downloaded. Please note: Anything you delete from webmail account will get deleted from an imap account, because imap accounts can only show whatever is on the server. So be careful what you delete. Empty the server Spam folder and Empty the Server TRash.

IF in Thunderbird, the Inbox Properties Quota said it was full, then you need to fix in Thunderbird. Copy important emails into a suitably named folder in 'Local Folders' mail account. Please double check you can still read that copied email. If copy is good then delete the original from the Imap folder. Repeat for all important emails. Finally... Right click on imap folder and select 'Compact' to remove all the old traces of moved emails from file. This should free up some space. You can check how much space is available via Properties > Quota.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
The first comment above is all about getting information about the set up so we offer further advise. It's also checking to see if issue is because there are no emails on server - which in turn is caused by you using up all the allowed space.

Sometimes servers change settings and if you are not up to date then things stop working. The requested information will allow us to check you are using the correct settings for the server.

If you are getting any error pop up messages then please tell us about that error message. Best option is to post an image of the error message OR type word for word the exact error message and make sure there are no typos.
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: flasunvee

content:
message "Login to account failed." Refusing a password does not necessarilly mean a wrong password there can be other reasons hence why i asked you for other information so we can check all server settings ?

In my first comment I asked for some basic information to undestand your setup. I really need you to answer all questions because I still have no idea what server you are trying to connect to nor whether you can access webmail or what type of account you use. Some servers change requirements, but I cannot just guess, I need information.

Stored Passwords:

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll down to Passwords section
  • clickon 'Saved Passwords' button
  • Clickon 'Show Passwords' button

Q 1 :Does the stored incoming password for the account match the same/identical as the stored outgoing smtp password for account?

re :I use this account several times a day, but last incoming message shows 9:09 am and it is now 3:52 pm.

that implies you are able to get initial access when you first start up Thunderbird. Q:2: Can you see newer emails on the server when you logon to webmail account ? Q 3 Are you able to logon to webmail account via a browser using that password ?

Q 4 In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • scroll down to 'Mail and News Account' section
  • Copy all the information/data in that area and paste it into this forum.

Q 5: Is this an Imap mail account ? IF yes - right click on Inbox > select ' Properties' > select 'Quota' tab - what is the quota % ?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
The outgoing server is mobile.charter.net, port 587, STARTTLS security, authentication = normal password, User Name = email address.

https://www.spectrum.net/support/internet/email-settings/

I have not seen Charter accounts @chartertn.net, instead of @charter.net.
creator: sfhowes

content: Thank you sfhowes. I changed connection security from NONE to STARTTLS and authentication from NO AUTHENTICATION to NORMAL PASSWORD and sent a test. It timed out. The server responded: "Sending of the message failed. The message could not be sent because the connection to outgoing server (SMTP) mobile.charter.net timed out. Try again." I tried again, and again, and got the same message. I have had the email address for 20 years. I do note that in the link to Spectrum support that you sent lists server settings based on domain as bresnan.net, charter.net and spectrum.net but does not list chartertn.net.
creator: tedcomo

content:
If all settings are correct, a timeout error is often due to an antivirus app that scans outgoing mail, e.g. AVG/Avast Mail Shield. If your AV app does this, it's recommended to add the TB profile folder as an exception or exclusion in AV settings.

Even then, I would contact Spectrum and find out if yourname@chartertn.net is a valid address.
creator: sfhowes

content: I use Windows security only. And the email address is valid because I'm able to use Spectrum online email to send until I get this problem fixed. I ran across this thread which is the identical problem that I have but his "fix" also doesn't work for me: https://forums.mozillazine.org/viewtopic.php?t=3110436
creator: tedcomo

content: Spectrum used to have odd settings for the smtp, i.e. the port was 587 but the security was SSL/TLS. Select SSL/TLS, and then manually enter 587 for the port, as it will default to 465 for SSL/TLS. Try that and see if sending succeeds.
creator: sfhowes

content: No, that didn't work. I tried various security/authentication methods with no success. I do notice that under No authentication, my user name is grayed out. It is not grayed out under any other authentication setting but doesn't work under any of them.
creator: tedcomo

content: This is interesting. As an experiment, I set up Outlook Mail. It asked only for my email address which I have it, said it was contacting the server, and finished setting up. I then used it to send a test message to myself. This is the result: InvalidRecipientsException: Invalid recipients were provided for the message: 'ba44' (550 5.1.1 <ted.como@chartertn.net> recipient rejected ). --> Unexpected SMTP server response. Expected: 250, actual: 550, whole response: 550 5.1.1 <ted.como@chartertn.net> recipient rejected Failure code: a6ba
creator: tedcomo

content: Since the attempt to send a test to myself via Outlook also failed, I attempted to send a test to my wife through Outlook (valcomo@chartertn.net.) It appeared to send it. So I went to my wife's laptop and there it was in her Thunderbird inbox. Then, I attempted to send it back to myself and hit reply, but her copy of TBird also returned the sender rejected message. Nor could I use TBird on her laptop to send mail to anyone else.
creator: tedcomo

content: Fixed it. Went into Outlook server settings to see how it was advised to set itself up by Charter. It listed incoming port as 993. TBird was 110. I changed it to 993. It listed incoming secure connection as SSL/TLS. server. TBird had None. Changed it to SSL/TLS. I also noticed that for authentication, TBird had Normal Password. Then on outgoing server, I changed c onnection security to SSL/TLS at port 587 and changed authentication from None to Normal password. The test went through. I sent another to a friend. It went through. Now, I'll make the same changed on the wife's laptop and hopefully, those settings will work for her too. Thank you sfhowes for taking the time to work with me. It's greatly appreciated!
creator: tedcomo

content:
Se hai il file pst di Outlook puoi convertirlo manualmente nel formato mbox di Thunderbird. Se ne parla ad esempio qui -> https://www.aranzulla.it/come-esportare-mail-da-outlook-29694.html

Una volta fatta la conversione, installa in Thunderbird il componente aggiuntivo ImportExportTools NG -> https://addons.thunderbird.net/it/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/ ed usalo per importare il file mbox ottenuto dalla conversione

Per Alice purtroppo c'è poco da fare. Ci sono molte segnalazioni di problemi. Ti ricordo però che l'accesso tramite client ad Alice è possibile solo usi una connessione Telecom (o almeno così sembra di capire...) -> https://www.tim.it/assistenza/assistenza-tecnica/mail/configurazione/protocolli-posta Se non hai una mail alice.it associata ad una linea ADSL/Fibra o mobile TIM, puoi configurare la tua casella di posta TIM Mail con protocollo POP3 o IMAP4, ed utilizzare questi protocolli nella configurazione di un programma di posta su PC o su mobile, solo se utilizzi una connessione Internet di TIM.

content:
The first thing to do is check the Server Settings.

Press Alt-e and choose 'Account Settings' from the drop-down menu that appears, then click 'Server Settings' under the HotMail account and enter these details:— 

 Server Name: outlook.office365.com  Port: 993 — for IMAP or 995 for POP  User Name: <your e-mail address>  Connection security:  SSL/TLS  Authentication method: OAuth2

Now click 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)' in the left hand column. Double click the 'Outlook.com (Microsoft)' entry and enter these details:— 

 Server Name: smtp.office365.com  Port: 587  Connection security: STARTTLS  Authentication method:  OAuth2  User Name: <your e-mail address>

GMail should have in 'Server Settings':—

Server Name: imap.gmail.com 

 Port: 993   User Name: <your e-mail address>  Connection security:  SSL/TLS  Authentication method: OAuth2

In 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)' > 'Google Mail':— 

 Server Name: smtp.gmail.com  Port: 465  Connection security: SSL/TLS  Authentication method:  OAuth2  User Name: <your e-mail address>
creator: ThePillenwerfer

content: - click 'account settings' - scroll down left side to 'outgoing servers (SMTP) and click there - on this pane, you can create new SMTP servers. be sure that the DESCRIPTION field is unique. you will need that when connecting to an account. - now, click an account within the 'account settings' pane that needs a server and at bottom of the accont pane is a link to the assigned SMTP server. That is a dropdown menu and click the one with the right description.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thank you, david! I thought that's what I needed but couldn't find the right button to click -- and no wonder -- it was at the top of the page in plain sight.  :)

I'm up and running again on all computers but am curious how that could have happened on all three computers (two of which did not have TB running when I got the power outage. Roadrunner assured me by phone that they haven't recently changed their login policies and so the only other thing I can think of is that TB just now updated to a version that will no longer support the concept of a <Default> SMPTE server. That would not explain, however, why this help board is not flooded with similar complaints. Would appreciate your thoughts just to satisfy my curiosity. Thanks again.
creator: joehimself

content: What you experienced is a common problem here, usually because the user consciously did that and, later, the email provider began to enforce the security issue. This is happening because email providers are increasing security by demanding that users of their servers be customers and the SMTP authentication does that. In your case, I wonder if you found several SMTP servers already there on that screen. DId you? Or was there just one when you added the others? My 'guess' is that thunderbird allocated the right SMTP server but, since there was no name in description field, when you reactivated thunderbird, things went kerflooey (pardon the technical term...) This is enforced by the email host, not thunderbird. Anyway, I'm glad all is well.
creator: davidsk

content:
4 of 8 accounts had SMPTE entries; 3 of which tried to use the address of the default account and another that tried to use the roadrunner mobil SMPTE URL. (??)

My 4 other accounts had no SMPTE entries at all. Again, this happened on all 3 computers and I fixed them all by giving each one their own (passworded) SMPTE URLS. (Which I made sure the passwords of each account matched on all computers).

Cheers.
creator: joehimself
